'''Anders Nicolai Kiær''' ([[Drammen]], 15 September 1838 – [[Oslo]], 16 April 1919) was a Norwegian [[statistician]] who first proposed that a representative sample rather than a complete enumerating survey could and should be used to collect information about a [[Statistical population|population]].<ref>Bellhouse, D. R. (1988). A Brief History of Random Sampling Methods. Handbook of Statistics, Vol. 6 pp. 1-14 Elsevier.</ref>

He was born in [[Drammen]]<ref name=snl>{{cite encyclopedia |year=2007 |title=Kiær, Anders Nicolai |encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]] |publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget |location= |url=http://www.snl.no/article.html?id=629648 }}</ref> as the son of ship-owner Niels Andersen Kiær (1802–1887), and brother of physician and historian [[Frantz Casper Kiær]].<ref name=snl2>{{cite encyclopedia |year=2007 |title=Kiær |encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]] |publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget |location= |url=http://www.snl.no/article.html?id=629642 }}</ref> He graduated as [[cand.jur.]] in 1860, and was hired as head of the statistics department in the [[Norwegian Ministry of the Interior|Ministry of the Interior]] in 1868. In 1877 he was appointed director of the newly appointed office [[Statistics Norway]], staying in this position until 1913.<ref name=snl/> Before 1882 he functioned as a co-director together with [[Jakob Mohn]].<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|year=2003|title=Jakob Mohn|encyclopedia=[[Norsk biografisk leksikon]]|first=Einar|last=Lie|volume=6|editor=[[Knut Helle|Helle, Knut]]|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo|url=http://www.snl.no/.nbl_biografi/Jakob_Mohn/utdypning|language=Norwegian|accessdate=5 April 2009}}</ref>

Anders Nicolai Kiær was a nephew of [[Hans Andersen Kiær]] and first cousin of businessmen [[Hans Theodor Kiær, Sr.|Hans Theodor]] and [[Anders F. Kiær]]. The latter founded the company [[And. H. Kiær & Co]].<ref name=snl2/>
